==Chinese==
{{zh-forms}}

===Glyph origin===
{{liushu|p}} – two arrows, tied together to be straightened.

Later borrowed phonetically to mean “no”. The derivative [[拂]] stands for the original word in Modern Chinese.

===Etymology===
See etymology of [[不]].

===Pronunciation===
{{zh-pron
|m=fú
|c=fat1
|h=
|mn=hut
|w=
|mc=y
|oc=y
|ma=|ma2=
|cat=adv,pref
}}

===Definitions===
{{zh-hanzi}}

# {{lb|zh|obsolete|or|dialectal}} not.

====Usage notes====
* In modern Chinese, This character is almost entirely used for phonetic translations. The character mainly represents the phoneme /f/ in word-final and preconsonantal positions.
* The characters {{zh-l|不}} and {{zh-l|否}} are far more commonly used to mean “no”.

===References===
* {{qualifier|Min Nan}} [http://kaifangcidian.com/han/minnan/%E5%BC%97 Kaifang Cidian]

==Japanese==

===Kanji===
{{ja-kanji|grade=uc|rs=弓02}}

# [[fluorine]]
# the [[dollar]] sign ([[$]])

====Readings====
{{ja-readings
|goon=[[ほち]] (hochi) {{qualifier|rare}}
|kanon=[[ふつ]] (futsu)
|kun=[[ず]] (zu) {{qualifier|rare}}, [[どる]] (doru)
}}

===Etymology 1===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|フッ素|フッ素 (Fluorine)}}
{{wikipedia|Fluorine}}
[[File:Liquid_fluorine_tighter_crop.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|弗}} (''futsu''): a sample of chilled liquid '''[[fluorine]]'''.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|ふつ|yomi=on}}
Originally borrowed from {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=ふつ}} {{m|ltc|弗|tr=*pjut}}, meaning either “not” or “a [[gust]] of [[wind]]”. Apparently later repurposed during the later [[w:Edo period|Edo period]] for its phonetic value (and possibly also for its “wind” → “[[gas]]” connotations) in translating the {{etyl|de|ja|sort=ふつ}} {{m|de|Fluor||fluorine}}.

The modern {{cog|cmn|氟|tr=fú||fluorine}} appears to be a more recent invention based on this Japanese usage, adding the [[radical]] {{m|mul|sc=Hani|气}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=kanon|ふつ}}

====Affix====
{{ja-pos|affix|ふつ|フツ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=ふつ|chemistry|chemical elements}} [[fluorine]], [[fluoride]]

=====Derived terms=====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-l|弗化|ふっか|fukka}}: [[fluoridation]]; [[fluoro-]], [[fluor-]]; [[fluorinated]]
* {{ja-l|弗化カルシウム|ふっかカルシウム|fukka karushiumu}}: [[calcium fluoride]], [[CaF2]]
* {{ja-l|六弗化リン酸リチウム|ろくふっかりんさんりちうむ|roku fukka rinsan richiumu}}: [[lithium hexafluorophosphate]]
* {{ja-l|弗化水素|ふっかすいそ|fukka suiso}}: [[hydrogen fluoride]], [[HF]]
* {{ja-l|弗化水素酸|ふっかすいそさん|fukka suiso san}}: [[hydrofluoric acid]]
* {{ja-l|弗化物|ふっかぶつ|fukkabutsu}}: [[fluoride]]
* {{ja-l|六弗化硫黄|ろくふっかいおう|ろくふっかいおう|roku fukka iou}}: [[sulfur hexafluoride]]
* {{ja-l|弗酸|ふっさん|fussan}}: short for {{ja-l|弗化水素酸||fukka suiso san}}: [[hydrofluoric acid]]
* {{ja-l|弗素|ふっそ|fusso}}: [[fluorine]], [[F]]
{{der-mid}}
'''Purely phonetic uses:'''
* {{ja-l|阿弗利加}}, {{ja-l|亜弗利加|アフリカ|Afurika}}: [[Africa]]
* {{ja-l|阿弗利加系亜米利加人|アフリカけいアメリカじん|Afurika-kei Amerikajin}}: an [[African American]] {{qualifier|person}}
* {{ja-l|阿弗利加野驢馬|アフリカのろば|Afurika noroba}}: the {{vern|African wild ass}}: {{taxlink|Equus africanus|species|noshow=1}}
{{der-bottom}}

=====Usage notes=====
Seldom used. In chemistry contexts, almost always spelled in [[katakana]] as {{ja-l|フツ}}, appearing in most compounds as {{lang|ja|フッ}}. This is probably a reflection of this term's roots as a {{m|ja|外来語|tr=gairaigo||word borrowed from another language}}.

===Etymology 2===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|ドル}}
{{wikipedia|Dollar}}
[[File:Dollar_Symbol_Evolution.svg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|弗}} (''doru''): evolution of the '''[[dollar]]''' symbol for both the [[w:United States dollar|United States]] and (now obsolete) [[w:Spanish dollar|Spanish]] dollar.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|どる|yomi=kun}}
Repurposed for its visual similarity to the [[dollar]] symbol '''[[$]]'''. This reading is ultimately a {{borrowing|ja|nocap=1|nl|sort=とる'|dollar}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=kun|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR|ドル}}

====Alternative forms====
* {{ja-l|ドル}}, {{ja-l|㌦}}

====Symbol====
{{ja-pos|symbol|ドル}}

# a [[dollar]]

=====Usage notes=====
Occasionally seen, but more often encountered in the katakana spelling of {{ja-l|ドル}}.
